text: I've been trying to contribute
um something about variety that I had
hoped and I haven't succeeded
um that I hoped would change the very
nature of the way theater is produced
and who comes to the theater because you
know the theater is a very segregated
place. Most of the people who run
theaters are in this country are white
people. My generation had many promising
directors and producers and and and and
writers and they're not around. They're
not making theater. And it breaks my
heart. And I feel in some ways
that I haven't contributed nearly enough
in terms of what my thought about that
was when I first was studying acting in
a theater where everybody on the stage
was white and everybody in the audience
was white. And I thought that's so
weird. Um, in San Francisco there's
Asian people up the hill. There's black
people across the bay. There's every
kind of person here. There's Latinos all
over the mission. How could this theater
of this town have everybody white on the
stage? Unless it was a black guy
bringing in a
pizza, a character bringing in the
pizza. Everybody in the audience is
white. How could that be? So I thought,
well, maybe if I figure out a way to
bring more colors of people onto the
stage, more colors of people will come
to the
audience. That hasn't happened.
So, you know, I think there's so much
work yet to be done in the American
theater so that it as a cultural form
can help
mirror the magnificent way that this
country has changed since the time I was
a girl in Baltimore. But I just don't
feel it has. And it breaks my heart. It
breaks my heart.
